questions.question: Which animal did Ivan Pavlov do experiments with?
Which one of these is NOT one of the learning theories we covered in Chapter 5?
In classical conditioning, before the subjects were conditioned to associate the metronome with food, the metronome was?
In classical conditioning, the word "condition" means

choices.answer: the circumstances under which the experiment is held
the state of the subjects after the experiment is over

questions.question: Which one of these concepts does NOT need to occur in order for classical conditioning to occur?

choices.answer: NS & UCS must come very close together in time - ideally less than 5 secs.
NS must be paired with UCS several times before conditioning can occur
NS must be similar to competing stimuli to become a CS

questions.question: The tendency to respond to a stimulus that is only similar to the original conditioned stimulus is what?
The disappearance or weakening of a learned response following the removal or absence of the unconditioned stimulus is?
What occurs when a strong CS is paired with a NS, causing the NS to become a second CS?
A learned emotional response by association is what?
What is John Watson most famous for?

choices.answer: training dogs to drool at the sound of a bell
experimenting with cats  in puzzle boxes
training a baby to cry when he saw a white rat
studying chimpanzees to learn about human problem solving skills

questions.question: What did Ms. Cover Jones do which was revolutionary for the field of psychology?

choices.answer: condition a little boy not to be afraid of something harmless
develop ethics which governed new moral qualities for field of psychology
discovered learned helplessness-later used this to develop learned optimism

questions.question: The development of nausea or an aversive response to a particular taste because that taste was followed by nausea is?
Behavior modification has its roots in what?
Which one of these people is associated with Operant Conditioning?
The learning of voluntary behavior through the effects of pleasant and unpleasant consequences to responses is?
Consequences which reinforce do what?
In Operant conditioning, consequences which punish the behavior do what?

choices.answer: provide spontaneous recovery for old behaviors

questions.question: In operant conditioning, punishment by application is

choices.answer: punishment by removal, escape from/avoiding the unplesant stimulus
punishment of a response by the removal of a pleasurable stimulus
punishment by the addition or experience of a pleasurable stimulus
punishment by the addition or experience of an unpleasant stimulus

questions.question: Which one of these is NOT necessary for punishment to be effective?

choices.answer: Punishment needs to occur when the misbehavior occurs.
Punishment needs to be intense enough to warrant change.

questions.question: A vending machine is an example of what?
A regular paycheck is an example of what?
Fishing is an example of what?
When a certain number of responses must be made before one of the responses is reinforced, this is what?
Gambling is an example of what?
A technique that consists of gradually molding a desired behavior by reinforcing responses is what?
The process where a behavior is ignored to suppress the behavior from occurring is called what?
What is learning through cognitive processes such as thinking, knowing, problem-solving, & remembering?
Who ran rats through mazes and developed the concepts of latent learning and cognitive mapping?
Who conducted observations of chimpanzees and developed the concept of Insight?
What is learning that remains hidden until its application becomes useful (reinforcement is provided)?
Who is associated with observational learning?
What does the concept of learning/performance distinction mean?

choices.answer: tendency to fail to act from a situation because of a history of failures
the individual demonstrates a behavior & serves as an example for learning
learning can take place without actual performance of the learned behavior
displaying a previously suppressed behavior after no threat of punishment

questions.question: Who shocked dogs and gave them an escape but watched them stay & developed the idea of "learned helplessness?"
Which one of these is NOT one of the elements of learning through observation?
Which one of these is NOT one of the different ways we learn through observation?
Which one of these points is NOT associated with Bandura's work?

choices.answer: Studies demonstrate how what a child is exposed to can affect his behavior.
Studies demonstrate how children are influenced by nonaggressive models.
Studies demonstrate that animals show aggression from modeling.
Studies demonstrate how children are influenced by aggressive models.

questions.question: Which one of these was NOT one of the implications from Bandura's studies?

choices.answer: TV viewing is more influential than watching live models before us.
Children do imitate behavior they see on TV.
Monitoring what children are exposed to is futile.
The study shows the magnitude that TV viewing has on our behavior.

questions.question: The modern term for a form of functional analysis and behavior modification that uses a variety of techniques is what?
Learning an involuntary response to a stimulus other than the original, natural stimulus that normally produces response
Stimulus, such as a stop sign or doorknob, that provides organism with cue to make a certain response to get reinforced?
What is instinctive drift?

choices.answer: learning that remains hidden with animals until its application is needed
animals tendency to revert back to genetically controlled patterns
animals learning by observation without actually having to perform the task
animal's relatively permanent change in behavior from experience/practice

questions.question: What is an example of a secondary reinforcer?
What is vicarious conditioning?

choices.answer: classical conditioning of involuntary response by watching others' reaction
the reappearance of a learned response after extinction has occurred
a complete made-up term to see if you studied Chapter 5 terms

questions.question: What is sharpening?

choices.answer: reinforcing simple behavioral steps to create desired behaviors
involuntary reflexes which are not under one's control or choice
another word 4 reinforcement  w/behavior modification/operant conditioning

questions.question: What is biological preparedness?

choices.answer: tendency of animals to learn associations like taste/nausea w/few pairings
animals' weakening of learned behaviors to survive
tendency for animal's behavior to revert to genetically controlled patterns
biofeedback w/brain scanning devices 2 provide feedback 2 modify behaviors

questions.question: You apply for and get rejected from your dream job twice. When the job posts again 2yrs later, you don’t even apply-why?
In Bandura’s studies on aggression in preschoolers, which group displayed the most aggressive behavior?

choices.answer: Kids who were exposed to live aggression
Kids who were exposed to aggression in a cartoon
Kids who were exposed to aggression on film
Kids who reportedly got bullied by older siblings

questions.question: We watched a clip of someone using operant conditioning to try to reinforce someone else’s behavior. Who was this?

choices.answer: Sheldon from The Big Bang Theory

questions.question: What was the dog’s name from the video I told u to watch? The dog demonstrated shaping through successive approximation.
What were Operant boxes later called?
In classical conditioning, what does the term “reflex” mean?

choices.answer: A naturally occurring stimulus that leads to involuntary/unlearned response
A stimulus that has no effect on the desired response prior to conditioning
An involuntary response, one that is not under personal control or choice
A learned response to a conditioned stimulus

questions.question: Where was Pavlov from?
In _?_ the conditioned response can briefly reappear when the original CS returns, but it is usually weak/short lived.
Which one of these individuals focused his research on observable, measurable behavior?
Which one of these features is NOT associated with classical conditioning?
Which one of these learning approaches could be summarized by asking “What’s in it for me?”
If calls from a bill collector motivated you to pay your bills on time, this would be reflective of the influence of?
The way people brush and floss rigorously for a few days before a dental exam is an example of what?
Grounding a teenager is an example of
A slot machine is an example of what?
Sometimes Skinner randomly dropped food in to his pigeons. To his surprise, what did they display as a result?
Which one of these is NOT a problem which could be associated with punishment?

choices.answer: The child could learn the wrong response
Severe punishment could cause the child to avoid the punisher
Severe punishment may encourage lying to avoid punishment
Punishment strengthens behaviors which is not always positive

questions.question: The term “operant conditioning” is rather synonymous with what?
Using objects (tokens) to reinforce behavior in which tokens can be accumulated & exchanged for privileges is what?
Any event or stimulus that, when following a response, decreases the probability that the response will occur again is?
Which one of these concepts did we NOT discuss after watching the realization scene with Rapunzel from “Tangled?”
Which one of these movies does NOT demonstrate observational learning?
What age group did the subjects for Bandura’s experiments with the Bobo doll belong to?
Who found parallels between learned helplessness and depression?
What year did Bandura conduct the Bobo experiments?
Who is associated with social-cognitive learning?
An animal’s capacity for learning is limited by its what?
Humans are very _______ averse.
What humans learn does not just shape our behavior. It also shapes our what?
With the concept of “latent learning,” the word “latent” means what?
Which one of these animals was NOT discussed as being the subjects of experiments with learning in Chapter 5?
In observational learning, modeling refers to what?

choices.answer: Following the example set by others

questions.question: What “fires” in your brain when you both perform an action and observe someone else doing so?
We watched a clip of someone who was able to successfully demonstrate classical conditioning. Who was this?

choices.answer: Leonard from The Big Bang Theory

questions.question: If I give my son an allowance every Sunday for cleaning the house, this is an example of what?
Learning how to play a song by watching your music teacher perform the song is an example of what?
Knowing which team to cheer for at a baseball game by watching your friend (an avid baseball fan) is an example of what?
If seeing your underage friend get away with drinking tempted you to do the same(don't do this, btw), this would be what
Your instructor chews out your classmate for talking in class, so you get really quiet. What is this called?
What might Pavlov’s dogs do if “Carol of the Bells” came on?
Why was Pavlov’s hair so soft?

choices.answer: Because he made regular trips to the salon
Because it had been shocked so much from all of his experiments
